Combined with the excellent acting, the John Hughes script kept the story moving at a good pace right from the word go.

Your feeling about this movie may depend on your own personal experiences. I was lucky enough to fall in love at first sight 36 years ago and have been in love with the same person ever since, so I believe that fairytale romances can happen. To me, watching "Maid In Manhatten" was a like reliving the thrill of a great romance all over again.

Jennifer Lopez's 10 year old son in the movie helped to make the story all the more believable and increased the viewers sympathy for his hard working mother. Some people did not like this movie because the end seemed predictable. So what! The journey to the end was a very enjoyable ride. 8 out of 10.

This brief review was inspired by another 'review' to set the other reviewer straight. Being a gringo myself, I'm probably not authoritative on the subject of Latinas working as housekeepers, but obviously she didn't "get" this film. Instead she chose to condemn every aspect (methinks because her life experience is so limited that she couldn't relate to any but the rich bitch in the film, who was basically the laughingstock).

So maybe the film wasn't intended for you as the primary audience, lady, and your conclusion about use of the Nora Jones song was silly (showing your insanity). Get over it. MIM wasn't great, but wasn't bad either--I gave it a 7, not a 1--fer Christ's sake, get real: it's a Columbia release with all of the trappings, admittedly not their best effort. At least not THAT bad. And who cares how cute you think Ralph Fiennes is--Jennifer Lopez's Latin looks are arguably better than Fiennes's vanilla looks. As was the point in this script, lady: you watch when Jennifer walks up and accepts her first Oscar a few years from now (she is that good). I'll be smiling and you'll be sulking, you sadly jealous person. Too bad your cup is half empty.

I don't go out of my way to see comedy romance movies, but I've seen my share to know when I see a bad one. Maid in Manhattan is an example of how not to make a comedy romance. Lopez plays a maid who falls for a guy who has loads of money (Fiennes, who is miscast, really) He thinks she is a guest in the hotel, she plays along. So she lies about herself for the rest of the movie and when all is revealed, it comes to a ridiculous ending. Sure does have production values though, and some of the scenes look great but this does not make a movie.

Wow. Does anyone remember how great John Hughes wrote scripts? The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Home Alone? What went wrong here? Wang, director of The Joy Luck Club, loses his spark here too.

There's not much else to say to this cinderella movie, except maybe that it's not funny. Lopez isn't a great actress, she and Fienness have about as much chemistry as a toothbrush in a toiletbowl. 4/10

This was a good decent film. It was a little slow. Lopez was pretty good in this movie but could have been a little better. The kid was great. He made the movie worth watching with his political talk.

The ending was also pretty good. I liked the thing with the magazines. All in all this was good film but would not mind watching again sometime.

What other romantic comedy did I miss?

But ya know what....I enjoyed it anyway. I am now officially in love with Ralph Fiennes. It is pronounced RAFE FINES, if I ever see him on the street someday. That man could have chemistry with a mailbox, he is so charming. He is my new favorite actor. I know, I know, "THE ENGLISH PATIENT"...yeah yeah yeah.

Oh, yeah and J. Lo is in it.

Let's see....nothing new here, but I still had fun. I am sucker for this stuff though. Chick Flick, Date Flick, etc.,

I do wish the second act played out a bit longer, a little more conflict, so that the "confrontation" scene wouldn't have felt so anti-climatic.

Cheesy music, cheesy dialogue....BUT I LOOOVED NATASHA RICHARDSON. SHE ROCKS!!

7/10

review_title: Not the best romantic comedy, but it had its moments.
review_detailed_main: This wasn't the best romantic comedy I've ever seen, but it had it's briefly humorous moments. I thought the cast was great especially the performances by Stanley Tucci, Natasha Richardson, Tyler Posey, and Bob Haskins. I think Jennifer Lopez has done better parts, but she wasn't that bad in this movie. If you're the kind of person that gets all "gushy" over these movies, I recommend it. I think you'll enjoy it. But, on the other hand i would recommend another movie.

review_title: Another romantic comedy for the pile
review_detailed_main: "Maid in Manhattan" is just your average romantic comedy, or perhaps even below the average. It's one of the most predictable movies you'll ever see. And I mean 'predictable' in a sense of 'obvious'; there are many other predictable movies out there that are nevertheless quite good. If you like this Cinderella innocent kind of romantic stories, by all means go see it. Just don't get your expectations too high (March '03).

Jennifer Lopez, (Marisa Ventura),"Monster-in-Law",'05. played a great role as a maid in one of New York City's great hotels and was loved by all her other co-workers, male and female. A very polished Butler took her under his so called wing and guided her into a manger's position, which she was very well qualified to fill. Marisa is persuaded to put on an expensive outfit and becomes involved with a very well known politician running for the U.S. Senate, who is Ralph Fiennes, (Christopher 'Chris', Marshall), "Red Dragon",'02. Chris takes one look at Marisa and falls completely in LOVE and adores her fantastic body from head to toe. Films like this we have seen over and over again with basically the same story; however, I do believe that Jennifer Lopez did a great job of acting and looked like a sexual bomb shell.

This was a decent romantic/mistaken identity movie that I really enjoyed. Jennifer Lopez played a maid in a posh Manhattan hotel when a Senator dropped by. Lopez is just trying to make a decent living and a better life for herself and her son, and she is in the room of a socialite and trying on the lady's clothes when the Senator walks in. Of course he thinks she is the socialite, falls in love with her, and starts taking her out to a whole bunch of important parties and functions, while chaos ensues at her real job and life. I think this was a funny and refreshing movie that you will thoroughly enjoy if you watch it. Lopez and Ralph Fiennes are perfectly cast in it. You will not regret seeing it.

*** out of ****

review_title: A Soft Side For Ralph Fiennes
Not even bad enough to be good, if you know what I mean...
review_detailed_main:
It's just plain bad. Boring, trite, clichéd, so chock full of cheese and cringe-inducing moments that I got a tension headache from scowling at the screen too much.

J-Lo.....How can one woman go through a whole film with only one hairstyle. Not just only one, but an unglamorous one at that. Shame that, despite this attempt to make J-Lo look homely and normal, her make-up looked flawless every day she turned up for work.

Mr Fiennes.....oozes all the sex appeal of a dead seal. Really makes me wonder what women see in men. In his character's case, money, obviously.

Bob Hoskins.... Oh Bob! What have you sunk to? You are completely wasted in this film. And by the way, I don't blame you for the awfully cheesy speech at the end, Bob. I know it was the writers fault. Just don't do another stinker like this again! OK?

Natasha Richardson.... I feel pity for you. How to make yourself look ridiculous and not get any laughs out of it. So sad.

Sundry other unimportant actors that played maids....Awful overacting, just awful. Go back to daytime soaps. Please!

As for the story. Bland and insipid. Full of hideously bad dialogue and scenes so contrived you could see them coming before you even got out of your car in the cinema parking lot.

But the most awful scene of the movie? The one where the maids stage an impromptu dance of victory in the bowels of the hotel, accompanied by music from nowhere in an attempt to hide their comically bad gyrations. Actually, thinking about it, that's really the best scene in the movie.

Everything is so predictable and dull. The only vaguely interesting moment comes when J-Lo's character is "found out" and the ensuing firing scene. But even this is marred by the "resignation" of Bob Hoskin's butler character, apparently as a show of solidarity with J-Lo's, and the direly awful speech which ensues, which is on a schmaltz level similar with Sam Gamgee's speech at the end of the LOTR movies.

Someone recommended seeing this with your girlfriend. I really don't think that's a good idea. All you're gonna do is p*** her off by snickering at inappropriate moments, or snoring during the love scene.

Oh, and whilst I mention the love scene, which was mercifully brief and thankfully didn't feature J-Lo's rotund posterior, I have to say that the song they chose to accompany the scene has to rate as the most depressing I've heard in a long while. I half expected the obligatory "next morning" shot to feature them both dead on the bed with slashed wrists.

Anyhow, it just goes on and on until the tedious and entirely expected conclusion where the two get together. Resist the urge to leave early to avoid the rush to the car park - the final "newspaper-and-magazine-front-page-montage" is so terribly, terribly bad its almost worth watching the film for that scene alone. Almost.

OK, so its a chick-flick, and I'm a guy so I don't get it. But why can't Hollywood take a leaf out of Disney's book? When they make a film for kids, they put in adult humour to keep the parents amused. Why can't chick-flick film-makers put in something for guys to enjoy? Would it be so hard? Maybe an explosion here, a monster there. That sort of thing.

OK, so I'm being flippant here. But it really grates on my nerves that we get served the same pap over and over again, with different actors repeating almost identical lines and doing almost identical, retarded scenes to countless films that have gone before.

I weep for modern cinema.

review_title: Walking in cold rain is preferable...Pretty Woman, La Vida Loca style!

review_detailed_main:
It's fun to wonder what bills Ralph Fiennes had to pay off so badly that his agents forced him to do this film, but other than that there's not much to viewing this lumbering overblown 'cinderella' story. J-Lo stars as a poor hispanic person who cares, but really it turns out her life would be so much better if she just hooked up with the right rich white man. I would hardly call this movie an enlightened version of the class struggle. (Oddly enough the only film that really dealt with race in a progressive way in J-Lo's 'cannon' would be Anaconda. I'm not kidding, either.)

Filled with more 'feel good' moments than a treacly Sandra Bullock trailer, this movie may entertain the 9 year olds who rushed out to see Glitter, but if you're an adult, just wait for the coverage of her next wedding, it's bound to be more entertaining.

review_title: Ralph Fiennes is looking fine but overall, an underwhelming romantic 'comedy'
review_detailed_main:
Jennifer Lopez plays single mum Marisa who works as a maid at a posh hotel in Manhattan. While trying on designer clothes belonging to one of the hotel guests during one of her shifts, Marisa meets American politician Christopher Marshall (Ralph Fiennes), who mistakes her for the guest staying in the room. As a result of the mutual attraction and fear that he will no longer be interested in her if he finds out that she is only a maid, Marisa fails to correct Christopher's assumption and keeps up the pretence.

As far as romantic comedies go, the poor girl and successful wealthy man fall for each other' theme in Maid in Manhattan' is an unoriginal one which has been presented more effectively with more charm and humour elsewhere (eg Pretty Woman' and American President'). An additional flaw is that for a romantic comedy, there are too few laughs. Attempts at humour lie predominantly with the supporting cast which includes Natasha Richardson giving an over-the top performance as the wealthy guest Marisa is mistaken for.

Early scenes of Marisa with her young son serve to convey the affection within their relationship. Unfortunately, my inability to warm to Jennifer Lopez as an actress is an obstacle and the overall effect is far too cutesy to be affecting. I have to say, the selling point of this film for me was the idea of Ralph Fiennes in a romantic leading role but unfortunately, there is uneasiness in his performance here and I actually find him far more appealing in more dramatic roles where he has been presented with a high quality script.

A Maid In Manhattan named Marisa(Jennifer Lopez) and her son Ty(Tyler Posey) meet the famous senatorial candidate Christopher Marshall(Ralph Fiennes). Marisa doesn't want him to know that she's a maid so she steals some clothes from a guest and pretends to be someone else. But then Christopher falls in love with her and sooner or later, Marisa is going to have to tell him the truth, will he or will he not, stay with her after he finds out who she really is? Well, i think you can guess that. The whole movie was very boring and predictable. Well, what can you expect from a Jennifer Lopez movie anyways? I would give Maid In Manhattan 4/10

review_title: How Could You Not Be Tickled by This Movie?
review_detailed_main: "Jenny from the Block" has a chance to shine in this romantic comedy because she worked with a truly talented cast, including that adorable precocious Garcia Posey kid, Ralph Fiennes and one of my all time personal favorites, Chris Eigeman. She's a maid, he's a senator on the campaign trail; they fall in love. I think director Wayne Wang did what he could with a silly Cinderella premise.

review_title: ok jennifer time to see u really act
review_detailed_main:
ok, first off i didn't love this movie. it was just ok, something to watch while ur cleaning house, it's very predictable though cute.

good points: yeah natasha richardson...very stereotypical rich b***h character, but i still enjoyed her performance bob hoskins also turns in a very nice performance as the training butler, and if there is any REAL lesson in this movie pay attention to his last statements to jennifer...that is a true lesson to be learned in life

as for miss lopez, i love her as a singer, actress...and it's no doubt she knows how to get through a romantic comedy (the wedding planner though showcases her much better) now i really want to see what she can do in a role with real drama. Enough was too run of the mill, and blood and wine was alright but i know there is more lurking in there...here's hoping she picks a role soon that has nothing to do with box office and salary, and maybe something that will take her to the oscars not just to present. 6 out of 10

The make-up people must have used a TON of gloop to cover up Ralph's red face on this one. Never a good smiler (let's face it) his attempts here at being warm and genuine are truly painful, and it's a miracle his face doesn't crack open from the effort. There's zero screen chemistry between him and Lopez, and the story is pure Hollywood factory output - unoriginal, uninspired, unfunny. A strong candidate for worst film of the year.
Are you people nuts??? This is a classic movie and well acted. Great story there's no reason for a bad review.

Ok, this movie isn't great, but it's still good fun. The actors aren't mesmorising, but they do a good job. I don't really think it should be classed as a romantic 'comedy' as it doesn't have many (if any) laughs, however it is one of those films that brings a smile to your face when you watch it. Watch it when it's raining outside, there is nothing on and you just want to snuggle up in front of the TV.

6/10

Maid in Manhattan is a typical Cinderalla story, it is also very trashy. J. Lo is terrible in this movie, she cannot act at all. I have never been big on Romantic Comedies and this movie has made me think that there will never be a good one. Overall, 3 out of 10, it has some good lines but not enough to help the movie a lot.

review_title: Oh! Look how far Ralph Fiennes has fallen!
light frothy romantic comedy that rips off pretty woman but still manages to avoid being dreadful.
review_detailed_main:
I think I commented on this already a long time ago but I was reminded of it again in recent conversations about what makes a romantic comedy good. This is a light frothy romantic comedy that almost blatantly rips off pretty woman but somehow still manages to be entertaining(sort of.)

Make no mistake, this isn't a good movie. The chemistry between the two leads while not being weak isn't TERRIBLY strong. Also there is not a shred of originality through any of it. And lastly, and perhaps most problematic is JLO as the maid. Did anyone really buy her in this role? It was a bit laughable.

Still, this is a good movie to watch if there isn't anything else on because it is mildly entertaining and sweet. Absolutely no thought is needed when viewing it so if one is coming off a tough week and just wants to relax-why not? But there are TONS of better, more kooky romantic comedies out there and I just did a review on one of them(two weeks notice).This(maid in Manhattan) does have glamor(show me a JLO movie that doesn't) so THAT'S a plus. Because the movie manages to at least entertain I'd give it a 6. Can't hold a candle to pretty woman though.

I thought this film was just a remake and a not so good attempt of a remake of That Funny Feeling from the 1960's which Sandra Dee and Bobby Darin were in that version is much better. I thought Maid in Manhatten was a bit shallow in story and a bit predictable with the comedy. I would recommend seeing That Funny Feeling if you can it is available to buy and may be also available to rent. I am not a fan of remakes especially when the remake is recent as yes they made remakes in the 1950's but those remakes were at least as good as or better than the original. Please feel free to contact me at reiddavid1964@yahoo.com.au with your comments about this.

review_title: Charming Comedy Not to Be Compared to Others
review_detailed_main:
This film, starring the usually rigid, placid Ralph Fiennes with a jazzy, hip Jennifer Lopez seems like these two may need sometime to warm up to their very polar opposite personalities. Yet, in "Maid in Manhattan," the chemistry between the two was very subtle, touching, and nearly believable. Very much like the film "Notting Hill" with Julia Roberts playing the famous one and Hugh Grant playing the normal, streetguy; the same subtleness worked. So, in romantic comedies like these, they seem to pull off a very predictable plot with unrealistic circumstances very well because of the two (or three) characters warmth, which brings the whole film back down to earth.

Also, with good acting, it helps, too. And though these aren't Oscar worthy performances by Lopez and Fiennes, they certaintly are not unbearable to watch in any way. Remember the film "It Could Happen To You," from 1994? Very similiar fluff, but the very warm chemistry between Nicolas Cage and Brigitte Fonda was undeniably likable and admiring. And how about "America's Sweethearts" from 2000, which some people are comparing "Maid in Manhattan," to, as well? Hardly a good film, as nearly every character was selfish, using gags to get back at eachother and hopelessly stupid (Julia Roberts is the only one worth watching in the movie). A very bad comparison to this film. And what is missing from "America's Sweethearts"? A true romance, something to learn from, and comedy and melodrama we have already experienced enough.

So, enjoy this film as it is all that I have said above.

A pseudo-Latino-Cinderella story. It is shocking that Jennifer Lopez and Ralph Fiennes were paired for this romantic comedy, because, really, they don't have any chemistry on camera. Fiennes is a good actor so one wonders why he accepted such a stupid role in a movie that doesn't require of his acting but just of his posing. Lopez keeps trying the same role over and over, nor giving a chance to movies or genres that would suit her better.

The problem with any failed Cinderella story is that, the story being well known and part of our cultural baggage, needs of reinvention and talent to pass the test. That's why Maid in Manhattan is a failure , as there nothing new or original, just a different setting.

The acting is dreadful, the movie is not funny or entertaining, actually it takes itself too seriously, and it is not engaging at all.

It sounds shocking, but this is a Wayne Wang's movie! A waste of money.

No talent wasted whatsoever, though! :D

Let me first say that I love chick flicks. I'm a sucker for predictable, feel-good movies. So, when I went to go see Maid in Manhattan, that's exactly what I expected - not a whole lot of substance, but a movie that would let me leave the theatre with a smile on my face. Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed.

Maid in Manhattan in a horribly contrived yawn-fest filled with minimal charm, little on-screen chemistry, and a whole lot of corny dialogue that doesn't ever seem to flow. The plot, which at times was too ridiculous to believe (really, who actually falls in love with someone without even knowing their real name?), dragged on endlessly, too often resorting to dull cliches and meaningless yet supposedly moving monologues. It appears to me that the script writers of this film decided something to the affect of: "to hell with good writing, this film will succeed soley on Jennifer Lopez's fame!" Unfortunately, it does not... True, I did walk out of the theatre with a smile on my face, but I attribute that entirely to the fact that my sarcastically witty friends spent the entire movie mocking it...

Oh J-Lo. You're so talented but you got into some awful movies early on. Maid in Manhattan is an absurdly generic movie about a maid posing as a posh girl for one night, catching the prince's... Er, I mean rich guy's eye and them falling in love and him realizing that she's not who he thought she was but it doesn't matter because after a few days he just loves her TOO MUCH! It's so underwhelming, so blasé and uninspired that it's hard to really care about anything that's going on here. From scene one you know exactly how this movie is going to play out and it never veers from that course. It doesn't even bother to try and throw any real curveballs or anything, it just follows that romcom recipe to the absolute letter and it's super boring because of it.

This movie is now 20 years old. I recently watched it on tv for the second time and though it's not perfect, it's consistently entertaining and man, with everything going on in the world right now this is the perfect movie to take your mind off of things for a bit.

Ralph Fiennes' American accent is a bit dodgy but it doesn't matter. Every actor gives a good performance (seeing Natasha Richardson be hilarious made me a bit wistful, since she passed away years ago). However unbelievable the plot, this movie works. Only negative point is how Fiennes' character more than once says some pretty creepy sexist things dressed up as acceptable romcom clichés. And the ending could have been less abrupt. But again: this is a well made feelgood film worth your time.

"Maid in Manhattan" is so predictable. This movie is like all those other movies about how a guy or girl pretend to be a certain way and when their love finds out they have this other life, there is the dramatic fight. And then , of course, their love comes back, apologizes, and they "learn" to love each other just the way they are. Don't get me wrong, the movie is cute and entertaining, but I am sure all of you know how the movie is going to end by just seeing the commercials.

Absolutely and utterly offensive in every possible way. If you think the plot to this movie is ok then you need to have a look at yourself in the mirror. So bad that when I went to the cinema to see this with on a date I got up after half hour and walked out and didn't go back. Never saw that chick again as making out and cheap grope isn't worth sitting thru this film. Offensive to anyone Mexican, Cuban, American, British, Chinese, Korean, Swedish, Black, White, Male or Female. A abysmal film. Would rather eat glass, infected with hepatitis and soaked in COVID than watch this. I don't think that anyone would enjoy this abomination.

John Hughes of 'Breakfast Club' fame came up with the story for this under a pseudonym and it shows because it has many of the elements of his famous 80's teen films.

I almost wish he'd gone a bit further and written the screenplay or even directed, because he could have boosted this film a lot.

As it is this film is OK. Nothing special, just OK. It has its moments, and boasts a decent performance from Jennifer Lopez, who could probably do this sort of film in her sleep.

The big thing that stopped me fully enjoying this film was the fact that I just couldn't buy Raiph Fiennes as the male lead in a romantic comedy. He seemed to have zero chemistry with Lopez and almost like he was out of place.

Overall, an average romantic comedy.

As my friend and I were leaving the theatre, she said she preferred Pretty Woman to Maid in Manhattan - I disagree totally! 1) I'll take Ralph Fiennes over Richard Gere any day. Isn't this what the romantic comedy is about? Ralph's eyes penetrate the screen, which is why he's such a good actor. Richard's are fine, but they can beady too. If I'm going to spend time watching fluff, it needs to be fluff with nice eyes. 2) I'd rather be a maid than a pro. Part two of what romcoms are about is being able to see oneself in the femme role. Hollywood needs to realize working the streets is not romantic or comedic. Okay, neither is changing sheets and cleaning toilets, however at least it's something people can respect at the end of the day. If I were going to try to emulate a movie, I'd be more inclined to get a job as a maid and hope Ralph walks in than work the streets and hope Richard picks me up.

This film is as formulaic as a Harlequin romance. Having said that, if you like the predictability of romance novels, this film might appeal. At least you won't have to think about the plot. Jennifer Lopez is appealing, but Ralph Fiennes has very little romantic sizzle. When they kiss, it's like watching a brother and sister - no spark.

What happened to the GOOD romantic comedies? Such as Pretty Woman, Only You (Marisa Tomei), When A Man Loves A Woman, Forget Paris, etc.????

Maid In Manhattan was an okay film, but I've seen Jennifer Lopez in better films. I would recommend this one, but no need to rush out to see it - a movie rental is just fine for this one.

If you want to see a real romantic movie, see Notting Hill, Shadowlands or Sleepless in Seattle... this movie is without any charm or romance really... not what I consider truly romantic. My question is, why do people sleep with each other and THEN find out how each other really are? It's all too predictable without much mystery and the story didn't allow the "real feelings" develop between characters. I felt that the relationship aspect of their "love" hadn't had much time to really develop. The focus of the movie seemed a lot to be on J. Lo's onscreen son. It was an okay film, but i'd definitely wait to rent it.

Personally, I loved this film. It's very sweet and nice and romantic and a typical rom com. Perfect if you are in feeling in any way depressed because it is sure to pick you up. And if you aren't feeling depressed it'll make you feel even better! It is romantic, and... rather typical of rom coms, but who's to say that the stereotype isn't enjoyable? I think Jennifer Lopez acted very well in this, and had great chemistry with Ralph Fiennes, who took up the mantle of sweet, leading man with surprising ease, showing his range and versatility, from manic villains to romantic senators.

So, definitely worth a watch I say, however, if you are slightly immature in your tastes, or in some way have an aversion to anything sweet or romantic, and maybe even at times remotely cheesy (in that sweet romantic way) then it's best to give it a miss.

For everyone else, I think it is definitely worth watching, I found it an incredibly enjoyable film, being eclectic in my tastes.

There were moments when I had to hug a cushion it was so... squeeable...
Nothing new about poor girl meets rich man.....Ho Hum..... This should never have made it to film. We have all seen this before. Acting was fair. Ms. Lopez can do better.....

1. Jenny Lopez is great and well cast in a sweet but unoriginal fantasy. 2. Fiennes is a great actor but hopelessly miscast here. 3. The first twenty minutes are so dull I almost walked out. 4. It says something about the kind of people who go to see a film like this that I was the only one who got most of the jokes. 5. Was it wise for J-Lo to do this movie? Instead of thinking about how beautiful she is, I'm left thinking she's plain enough to be a maid. 6. The person whose fault it was that I was watching this rubbish turned to me at one point and said "It's like Gosford Park". That was the best moment of the evening.

Adrian

"maid in manhattan" is one of the if not the best romantic comedy of 2002! jennifer lopez and ralph fiennes are a perfect match! its just so sweet and heartfelt. i can only pray that 2003's romantic comedies are as good as this one and i cant wait to see if columbia pictures does a new and improved special edition of this enchanting flick!

I could honestly say that this movie defines "chick flick" Not to say I didn't enjoy it, but its very comperable to Pretty Woman and exceedingly predictable. I enjoyed it, but would recommend waiting til it comes out for Rental. If you're looking to see a movie in a similar genre to this, I'd recommend My Big Fat Greek Wedding instead.

review_title: Fantasy loce story undon by silly ending.
review_detailed_main: This is a breezy romantic comedy about a maid (Jennifer Lopez, who doesnt look or act like a working class woman) who thru mistaken identity winds up romancing a Senatorial candidate (Ralph Fiennes, not an ideal romantic lead). A fluffy comedy that as a fantasy love story is somewhat entertaining but it kinda becomes unwound in a ridiculous final sequence that defies logic. GRADE: C+

A real retread. Take out Jennifer Lopez, plug in Julia Roberts, Doris Day, Debbie Reynolds or whoever the movie "sitcom" queen of the moment is or was. It was well produced (slick), well acted on auto-pilot, and ultra predictable. Boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl. Aimed at the dumbed down masses.

review_title: She's cute, but not much else is good about it

review_detailed_main: This film is a pretty much a shot to shot remake of how I met my wife in laindon who also use to be our maid.

Christopher Marshall (Ralph Fiennes), Marissa Ventura (Jennifer Lopez) and her son, Ty (Tyler Posey), scale a Central Park rock formation surrounded by lush trees as they gaze over the horizon lined with Manhattan's skyscrapers in director Wayne Wang's Maid in Manhattan. One of the characters states the obvious: `It's like two different worlds.' Later in the film, Ventura's best friend, Stephanie Kehoe (Marissa Matrone), uses the same line to convince Ventura that efforts to pursue a relationship with Marshall will be in vain.

Screenwriter Kevin Wade resisted subtlety in this modern Cinderella story, and the entire film is predictably predictable and laden with flat characters. Marshall is the smooth Republican senatorial candidate with captivating blue eyes and the perfect smile. Ventura is the beautiful and intelligent maid who deserves a more luxurious life than the one she lives in the Bronx. Ty is the ideal son who serves as Marshall and his mother's love catalyst. Jerry Siegel (Stanley Tucci), Marshall's campaign manager, suffers from constant anxiety and stress due to Marshall's public behavior and inability to concentrate on the senatorial race. Ultimately, the final credits roll an unending list of prototype characters.

But Maid in Manhattan surprisingly emerges as a simple but enjoyable cinematic delight. The lessons of the film are simple but poignant and important in the tradition of many holiday classics. Ventura reminds Marshall that societal problems are daily realities rather than matters of political debate for large populations that, on many levels, understand political issues more viscerally than governmental candidates who use the issues to secure votes and a desirable public reputation. The butler, Lionel Bloch (Bob Hoskins) tells Ventura, `What we do does not define who we are.' Ventura's friends support the unfortunate truism that it's not about what you have or what you know but about who you know. Finally, Ventura gives people hope that any dream-as impossible as it may seem-is truly attainable.

Audience members will recognize the many lessons of the film do little but to reinforce common knowledge, and they will also recognize that Maid in Manhattan enjoys success because of the well delivered performances by Fiennes, Lopez, Posey and the supporting cast. Fiennes and Posey share the first satisfying moment long after the opening scene of the film with their engaging conversation in the hotel elevator. The three main characters-those played by Fiennes, Lopez and Posey-share the next entirely pleasurable scene with two French women in the same elevator, and at this point the film finally reaches its tolerable pace. Fiennes did not have much material to create an extremely compelling and dynamic character, but he achieves in portraying a charming and self-admittedly less-than-perfect politician.

Lopez struggles onscreen until her onscreen chemistry with Fiennes rescues her from a rigid performance. Once she relaxes, however, she delivers an endearing performance. She is sweet but capable of dishonesty. Vulnerable but aggressive. Common but inexplicably highly extraordinary. She is human. Lopez is not an accomplished screen veteran, but she does not always make the obvious acting choice, which sets her apart from other actresses with similar screen experience. She carries an embodied knowledge of the truth that minorities are often `stereotypes or invisible,' and this understanding makes her shine in scenes that deal with this difficult issue.

Tucci illustrates the point that memorable performances are a product of quality rather than quantity in terms of screen time. His character not only must deal with the fact that Marshall is a campaign manager's public nightmare, but he also must endure professional humiliation when Marshall gives him extra duties as his beloved dog's caretaker. He is not subtle, he pushes the panicked and anal campaign manager caricature to an extreme, his character's personality is entirely unlikable and yet audience members walk away loving the unlovable Jerry Siegel.

Maid in Manhattan does not deserve a Best Picture nomination or any award nomination for that matter, but one must doubt that Wayne Wang or any member of the creative team set out to create an Oscar-winning sensation. In one respect, this is a sad commentary on the entertainment industry and general artistic integrity. In an ideal world, artists would only sign on to pictures that they believed would achieve the highest expectations of the industry. As every person knows, however, this is not an ideal world, and sometimes the only goal is to create an entertaining blockbuster hit. In these terms, the film is a definite success, and to criticize it for lack of artistic merit or originality is asinine as it never claimed to be anything more than an updated version of the Cinderella story.

review_title: Maid is not a must - see.
review_detailed_main: This is a weak film, but it is pretty to watch. Jennifer Lopez does an acceptable job as the hotel maid in this somewhat insipid story. I cannot recommend it as a must-see film, but I can tell that the audiences are flocking to see their idol, J-Lo.

Maid in manhattan would have been a lot better if the new york assemblyman wasnt ralph fiennes. I was thinking for about 10 minutes, wasnt he the creepy guy from red dragon? After that thought hit me, i couldnt think of him as a romantic sort of guy, he seems more able to portray a murderous man that lives in a old, dank, house where he takes commands from a painting... Jennifer lopez didnt really sell the performance as a maid, and the movie seemed to be holding on to the cinderella concept too tight, and should've let go and let it breathe a little. What is the deal with the kid hooking the two of them off, it came off as an attempt to bring back the parent trap. (C- D+)

review_title: A failure at a near perfected genre
review_detailed_main: How hard can it be to take two beautiful stars and try to create some chemistry? Romantic comedy. I didn't expect anything brilliant in any area, but what I got was actual boredom. I couldn't wait for the next scene in the hopes that there would be SOMETHING for me to grasp onto. I should say that the boy who plays Ty is irresistable and the only standout performance. If you want a cute, funny, charming romantic comedy, please check out Two Weeks Notice. It is a more capable vehicle.

review_title: "Energetic performances help this predictable romance, but only a little"
I will think twice before beating my maid again.
review_detailed_main: Quite often, usually once in the average life span, a film comes along to tear your heart out by the roots, wrench your guts, make it rather difficult to breathe, have you questioning your faith in The Almighty, and leave you in the woods at three o'clock in the morning waiting for a ride. MAID IN MANHATTAN is one of those films! What more could you dare to say about the director who has brought us LIFE IS CHEAP... BUT TOILET PAPER IS EXPENSIVE ? As a twenty plus year admirer of Wayne Wang, no, 'admirer' does not properly express my exultation, perhaps 'cult-like devotee' serves it more justice...I am left shell-shocked at the tour de force that is this film. MAID IN MANHATTAN is truly, utterly, and understandably Wayne Wang's magnum opus. One can plainly see many a night was spent pouring over its stunning script and casting decisions. And with good reason! Those sleepless nights paid off in many fold. J. Lo plays a brooding domestic care professional in a NYC lodging facility, oftenly slipping into philosophical musings on her humble station in life. Her intelligence and Shakespearean wit carry the screenplay to a place where no other screenplay, I have seen at least, has ever been carried. For the lower brow audience (whom I daresay you'll probably not catch dead renting this), J. Lo reduces herself to some clichéd one-liners and skimpy outfits, but any accomplished person of the brain will know she is doing it to make a social statement. We all know she is the Katharine Hepburn of the 21st century. The chemistry between she and Ralph Fiennes is nothing short of magical. After you watch his mind-blowing performance in this movie, you'll wonder how anybody can ever sit through SCHINDLER'S LIST again without doubling over in laughter.

review_title: kinda good - kinda bad - feel good movie
review_detailed_main:
Jennifer Lopez plays a Mexican American with a kid who gets her hooks into a politician.

Okay, first of all this movie was kinda good in that it showed a woman with a strong work ethic and who was intelligent. However I think it should have portrayed her as being a little more intelligent than she was in this movie. Too much weight was put on the kid doing unkid-like things. These were things she should have been doing herself to show that she and the politician really did have something in common other than a sexual attraction.

Also I don't know why but all of JLo's movies leave me with an uncomfortable blank feeling. This one did too, but it wasn't as bad as the Wedding Planner which the thought of still gives me the creeps. Ugh...remember the M&M's in the park where they were throwing away all the red m&m's? Yeck that was just soooo stupid.

So anywho, it's a feel-good movie with a little to be desired but it WILL make you feel good. And for that reason it's worth seeing if there is nothing else better available.

Being a great fan of the Romantic Comedy, I have to say I was so disappointed in this movie. I was sitting in the theater, less than thrilled about the performances, the script and the over all plot. It has been there and done that to many times. I couldn't wait until it was over with. It was boring and trite, and not worth my time really. I didn't even enjoy the clothes.

The only reason I watched this movie was because I am a huge fan of Ralph Fiennes, and would watch a soap commercial if he were in it. That being said, I was disappointed to find him in such an unrelenting puff piece playing second fiddle to JLo. I was comforted by the fact that at times he even appeared (albeit gracefully)uncomfortable!

This movie had an overall feel of a "let's star JLO in anything and cash in on her megacelebrity quickly before the new hottie comes along." I guess due to her media overexposure,I had a hard time being convinced that she was a single mom working as a maid, and her attempts at acting seemed flat and forced. As I watched the movie, that song "Jenny from the block" kept going over and over in my head. I didn't buy Ralph as an American Senator,either; he would have been better suited to play a Prime Minister, Royalty,member of Parliament, etc.

Natasha Richardson was great though, in her role, and provided much-needed comic relief to the script. The movie is pleasant enough, but not nearly as clever or emoting as "Pretty Woman", which it seems to loosely imitate at times.

I thought that this movie was a bit of a disappointment. It was entertaining, but I thought that it was kind of silly how they acted is if they had known each other for a long time and had some really deep relationship when they had only briefly seen one another a couple of times. That part of it just seemed unrealistic to me.

review_title: With some major changes, this movie would've been good
review_detailed_main:
If you have seen any sample of "romantic" Hollywood films, you've seen

this movie. It is therefore not recommended that you watch it, unless

you are going to write a movie script for another Hollywood movie. If

you do, consider shortening the movie to about half its length, and use

the remaining time to expand the last minute of the movie (before the

credits, of course). This, by the way, in no means implies that that

last minute is any better than the preceding many, but that they could

have been.

If one objects to profanity as I do, you have to be very careful in selecting what passes for a romantic comedy these days. Some film directors just have to throw the the random 'f' word just to make some ludicrous point about "pushing the envelope" or so they say. I found this one to be quite on the wholesome side. I also thought the acting was quite good from Jennifer Lopez in addition to being great eye candy as usual. Seeing her in the dress that shows up in at the fund-raiser was just about worth the price of the rental in itself.

Bob Hoskins (Who Framed Roger Rabbit) is turning into a fine character actor. So much so that he became the quintessential butler. I had to check the credits again to be certain that it was really him. My high grade is for excellent acting and direction, seamless editing and a good score. I would have subtracted several stars had there been a lot of profanity in it.

A highly recommended film in the vein of 'Pretty Woman' but unlike that title, this one can be watched with your family.

If you want to see a real romantic movie, see Notting Hill, Shadowlands or Sleepless in Seattle... this movie is without any charm or romance really... not what I consider truly romantic. My question is, why do people sleep with each other and THEN find out how each other really are? It's all too predictable without much mystery and the story didn't allow the "real feelings" develop between characters. I felt that the relationship aspect of their "love" hadn't had much time to really develop. The focus of the movie seemed a lot to be on J. Lo's onscreen son. It was an okay film, but i'd definitely wait to rent it.

review_title: big thrills for fans of romantic comedies

review_detailed_main: A four star rating may be an overly optimistic view to take of this improbable and often hyper-emotional chick flick, but the presence of two admirable actors, Ralph Fiennes and Stanley Tucci, redeems the movie from its morass of self-conscious sentimentality. The plot is slight, the imaginative embellishments are few, but still... Tucci, as the pragmatic, even caustic publicity liaison for candidate Fiennes, is always a refreshing presence. With his feet on the ground and his hand in the mix, he manages to create one of the most likable characters in the film, and certainly the most complex. As for Fiennes, his worth as an actor is impossible to ignore, even when he is improbably paired with Jennifer Lopez, and burdened with an insipid script. If you can suspend disbelief and censoriousness, and if you're suffering from a head cold anyway, you could do far worse for a film to fill a rainy day.

review_title: Typical romantic comedy benefits from star appeal

review_detailed_main:
My Rating: *1/2 out of ****.

Let me just say that I am not a fan of Romantic Comedies. I am not saying all romantic comedies are bad but I have never had the burning desire to see one. Todays Romantic Comedies are conventional, formulaic films. If they are well made they can be a joy, if not they can be painful. Unfortunately, its the latter statement that fits here.

Maid In Manhattan is a truly unoriginal and formulaic movie. But that usually comes with today's romantic comedies. All that needs to be done is for the film to be well-made. Maid In Manhattan fails.

I have always belived Jennifer Lopez to be hugely overrated. Shes a good looking woman with an atrocious ass but exhibits very little acting talent in anything I have seen her in. To be fair, She was good in Out of Sight but that was six years ago. Now, she is just flat out awful. I was like her, "Someone shoot her." Did I mention I hate her ass.

Ralph Fiennes does not fare better, but he outacts J.Lo (something that is clearly not hard to do). He has a funny moment but appears to be uncomfortable in the film(I do not blame him). Natasha Richardson is irritating and she needs to shut up. Bob Hoskins is underused but outacts most of the cast. Stanley Tucci does a solid job and provides some of the only comic relief in this bad film. The kid in this film is such a lousy actor. "Tell him hes fired" (A line from Diamonds are Forever, an underwhelming film but its a masterpiece compared to this drivel).

The best thing I can say about this film is that as unbearable as it is, it could have been a little worse. J.Lo maybe good looking except for her ass. I really hate her ass, I would love to pop it. I do not see what is attractive about it. On that note I conclude this review. This is drivel from Hollywood and drivel from J.Lo's ass.

you have seen the story before. poor girl meets rich boy. girl pretends to be somebody she is not. boy and girl fall in love. girl and boy are rudely ripped apart. boy and girl find one another again and live happily ever after. in this case it's lopez' marisa, a manhattan hotel maid, who pulls the wool over senate hopeful christopher marshall's eyes and earns his undying affection. he is attracted to her beauty and unaffected poise. she, in turn, swoons over his wit, respectful attentiveness and gentlemanly air. trouble awaits them, however. when the wealthy hotel guest gets wise to her dowdy doppelganger, she alerts the manager. marisa is, of course, promptly fired, and the ever-present paparazzi surrounding chris smell scandal. but popping flash bulbs and disparate bank balances are no match for true love. this is a perfect modern day cinderella story. also worth noting is that it is made known through marisa's conversations with her son that she either never married, is divorced or is separated from her son's father. the father's absence isn't lamented in any way other than in how it affects her son. thankfully, marisa does her best to insulate her son from the damage such a detached father can do while never insulting or berating the unseen man in front of the child. it is this kind of touch and depth which make this movie outstanding in its genre. in conclusion, the morals are solid. The acting is superb. the moments are touching. the sentiments are silky and sweet. for me, this is the best romance movie of 2002. my ratings for other 2002 romance movies i have seen are "life or something like it" 7/10, "sweet home alabama" 6/10 and "Two Weeks Notice" 5/10. highly recommended.

review_title: Loved it, a well-done romantic comedy
review_detailed_main: I saw Maid In Manhattan the day it opened and loved it. With its transparent Cinderella storyline in the background, this movie rocked. I found it more of a romance then a comedy. I think Jennifer Lopez did an excellent job. I wasn't impressed at all with her performance in The Wedding Planner. I think it was the aspect of the romantic comedy which was all new to her, which reflected on her performace. In Maid In Manhattan, I think she learned from her mistakes and did a much better job. Her character was perfect for her and she played it well. I never once found myself saying "That's phony" or "cheesy" or "corny" or whatever. Ralph Fiennes I felt was mediocre in this movie. His character was sort of boring and I think Ralph was poorly casted. However, I don't feel he was horrible. Many times I actually felt chemistry between him and Lopez. He's a good actor, but I believe he needs more experience at romantic comedies. As for the movie itself, I thought it was great. Natasha Richardson's character was hilariously funny to me (though I don't think it was meant to be) and I thought the little Tyler Posey did a job well done. The only part I did not like was outside the Met when Jennifer's character, Marisa was trying to tell Ralph's character Chris about her true identity. Chris kisses Marisa and I'm like "What the hell? She's obviously trying to tell you something important I think you better let her talk." But I think that was just the best excuse they could come up with to introduce a love scene between Chris and Marisa. But aside from that, I loved it. Yes, it was predictable but who cares? No one goes to see a romantic comedy to be surprised anyway.

review_title: Liked seeing JLO in a maid outfit!
Warm, endearing romantic fairy tale, albeit old-fashioned
review_detailed_main:
Jennifer Lopez is a young single mother and hardworking maid for one of Manhattan's fanciest hotels which tends to attract some of the biggest celebrities and power players. One of these famous guests is Ralph Fiennes, a young upstart Republican politician whose Senate campaign is picking up steam. Their chance encounter blossoms into an improbable romance that defies the odds.

I found this film charming, unpretentious and carefree, a welcome straightforward love story that takes place smack in the middle of New York's political arena and stark class differences, which even in 2002 were quite stark. The film's quiet emotional power overcomes a relative lack of realism. Anyone watching this film long after it came out would know that it was made during a more innocent period in American politics, before we as a country became inexorably and undeniably divided. My only complaint is the overblown depiction of mass media frenzy, with crowds of reporters seemingly present every waking moment.... sort of the anti-Slumdog Millionaire, a whole other kind of unrealistic.

Despite these occasional flaws, a film like this is not an anachronism but actually a reminder that love and hope can overcome all types of barriers, including economic and political. It may have been made during a happier, more prosperous era but I still believe in a love story that reaches for the sky when it comes to our better nature as human beings. For that reason, this film gets my warmest and happiest recommendation.

J-Lo does comedy!! I never thought I'd see a funnier movie!! Honestly....those who chastise this movie, don't understand or appreciate the rom-com genre and the place this movie has in it. Also to see her play a poor character when in real life she is rich shows that she is no diva.

With great supporting roles by some cute kid and Ralf Fiennes as the dashing hero this beats any Hugh Grant/Julia Roberts/Meg Ryan effort easily. The only unconvincing role was that of Bob Hoskins who didn't have a single funny joke in an otherwise riproaringly funny movie.

Hopefully they'll make a sequel soon!!!

review_title: A praise for an entertaining piece.
review_detailed_main: I really enjoyed this film. As a theater manager, I see a ton of formulaic romantic comedies come onto the screen. This movie, while predictable in a fairly traditional John Hughes fashion, was both entertaining and well thought out. Whereas you saw the typical romantic misunderstanding coming from a mile away, the way it was resolved was quite original, and that is an accomplishment in a romantic comedy.

review_title: Charming and innocent, but not too deep
review_detailed_main:
"Maid in Manhattan" was surprisingly delectable in an innocent sort of way. Jennifer Lopez's character is almost morally unblemished; she's meek, humble, and has a good head on her shoulders. Her relationship as a single mother with her son is true-to-life, even though there are very few child genuises in real life.

Ralph Fiennes is a great addition as well. He's a politician coming to terms with the balance of bureaucracy and humanity in making laws. Lopez assists him in this process in a way that fits nicely into the story. Even though the movie isn't about anything on a deep level, there's a good message beyond the chemistry.

Basically, this movie was worth the $5, and I was surprised that I actually enjoyed this chick flick. It's the best since "A Walk to Remember," and a good date film as well. Plus, you just don't feel as slimed or dirty when the lead actress doesn't walk around dressed like a slut all the time, especially when she has a kid.

I avoided watching this film for the longest time. Long before it was even released I had dismissed it as an over-hyped, over-blown, overly romanticized piece of Hollywood schmaltz, and I wanted nothing to do with it. I never watched it in the theater. I shook my head in disbelief even though I had never seen it. Then I was asked to be a judge at a high school public speaking contest. One of the girls, little Rosalina, spoke about this movie. "It was so great," she said. "You really felt like you were a maid in NYC falling in love with this rich dude." "Nonsense," I thought. I shared my feelings with my fellow judges. One looked at me and said, "you might be right, but if she liked the movie that much maybe she'll want to learn more about really being a maid. The movie must have done something right to get Rosalina so interested." "Well, maybe," thought I. Then it finally appeared on Pay TV. "OK," I thought, "I'll give it a look see." I didn't want to like it - and I didn't. I loved it! What a great movie.

Where to start? First - the directing. My high school public speaking contestant was right. Wayne Wang does a superb job of creating an almost "you are there" type of atmosphere. The gaiety of life inside the most elegant city in the world. The nonchalance of having to clean hotel rooms; then the rising sense of panic when she first meets Ralph Fiennes. You don't just watch it; you really do feel it. Then - the performances. The lead performances from Jennifer Lopez (as Marisa) and Ralph Fiennes (as the hot Christopher Marshall) are excellent - Lopez's being the superior, I thought, but both were good. They had their poor girl/rich boy characters down to a perfect "t" I thought. In my opinion, though, stealing the show was Jayne Howdyshell as Carmen.

Problems. Well, the romance was perhaps too contrived, in the sense that I just don't accept that Marisa could have moved so effortlessly from steerage to first class by stealing the gentleman's heart. (I know she was invited the first time; but he seems to keep getting into first class without being stopped until he's been there for a while.) The realities of the separation of the social classes were much more realistically portrayed, I thought, when Marisa and Christopher kissed for the first time.

A minor quibble, though. This is truly an excellent movie. My only regret is not seeing it in the theater, where I think it would have been so much more impressive.

9/10

review_title: As good as Meg Ryan's best-- J-Lo and Ralph Fiennes are charming and "truthful." Splendid fare!
review_detailed_main:
This is a solid romantic comedy--- happy ending and all. "Maid in Manhattan" is one of those rare fantasy type movies that doesn't challenge reality, but rather "smoothes" it somehow, compliments it, sparkles it up a bit, and makes every scene, and the overall vibe, very charming.

There were so many ways this movie COULD have been "Juila Roberts-y," or some other form of horrid dreck. I avoided seeing it for just that reason. But I read some good reviews, and also could not resist the inherent appeal of stars Ralph Fiennes and Jennifer Lopez. As it is, "Maid in Manhattan" was grounded in "truth." Not strictly factual truth, perhaps, but it has a satisfying resonance with my psychic and emotional giblets nonetheless. Even though as a "romantic comedy" you know there will be a happy ending (that's what the term "romantic comedy" traditionally means, it doesn't mean jokes per se), many times throughout the flick reactions, developments, and events were unexpected, and thus pleasant surprises.

This was as good as Meg Ryan's best work, with Ralph Fiennes adding a unique dimension. I really liked it!

review_title: You know it is a Cinderella story, so stop expecting something different and look deeper!
review_detailed_main:
I can't believe I didn't get to watch this until 2016, but there it is! So I am waaaay after the event, which is good, because I had no preconceptions and hype to go upon before viewing. As such, I started watching not expecting that much and was happily surprised. I initially only knew the leading lady was J Lo, so to find Ralph Fiennes as leading man, Natasha Richardson as the (beautiful) ugly sister and Bob Hoskins as the (male) fairy godmother, let alone Stanley Tucci running interference and a cute Tyler Posey acting their butts off was a great joy.

So many viewers will watch this film, regard it superficially as a chick flick type of film and therefore will be unlikely to ever bother watching it a second time or appreciate the amazing talent that went into making it - it is there to see if you bother to look, but so many are blind to much... and just want a quick watch, in which case this film will get a lower rating from them which is undeserved.

OK, the script could have been less predictable, but, as I said above, it IS Cinderella so you know what is coming anyway, whatever twists there are going to be... if any. As we all know the general plot so well and so many before me have already cited it ad nauseam, I'm going to pass right over that side of things and concentrate on what to me in this film really shines out - what to me makes it a very good film, rather than a nondescript one as with other cast choices would have so easily been the result... THE ACTING.

J Lo doesn't do her best performance ever, but is fine. However, Ralph Fiennes brings loads of little nuances to a pretty straightforward and what could very easily be a boring and one-dimensional part. Keep your eagle eyes on his facial expressions and his eyes, oh those eyes, those eyes.... the sign of a truly great actor is to act with their eyes. Considering it is a genre in which we rarely see him perform, all I can say is, what a shame it doesn't happen more often. All those male actors out there wanting to be a romantic lead, you would do well to watch Ralph's subtle performance and learn!

Natasha Richardson is brilliant, shamelessly hamming it up as the confused blonde. Heck, she reminds me in this film SO much of her mother. What a tragedy her loss is to all. And Bob Hoskins at his best - superb! Sadly, another huge loss.

Stanley Tucci, where would we be without you? I adore your contribution to this film and so many others! That scene with Rufus (the dog) outside the hotel is priceless! LOL! Watch his face, too... Many films otherwise without Stanley Tucci would be like bread without enough salt - you can eat it, but there is something missing... And a tiny Tyler Posey! He must have been about ten when this was filmed and did a great job with some pretty difficult lines at times. Very engaging and a great cast choice.

So, yes, if you just like straight up chick flicks, go and watch a chick flick. If you want to watch a (mostly) really well acted sweet romance and enjoy and want to watch it again, then watch Maid in Manhattan - I shall.

review_title: Owning our story and loving ourselves through that process is the bravest thing we'll ever do.
review_detailed_main: Have you ever impersonated someone else to win someone over? If you were considering it, this film demonstrates why you shouldn't. Do you realize how hard it was for Marissa to constantly rush about pretending to be Caroline Lane and keeping her job? I understand that she was in a precarious situation when the lie began, and that her buddy was pressuring her to take a chance with Chris. However, she was risking everything since she had no idea what would happen if her secret was ever discovered. I knew she had reached her limit when she was summoned to the hotel management office and Caroline was seated there. After revealing to Chris that she was a maid, she lost her job. It must have been the most embarrassing thing to endure. Fortunately, she was hired at another hotel where Chris was making a speech and they were able to reconnect.

Tivo recorded this as a suggestion, which surprised me because I don't watch many romance movies. I decided to watch, even though it was rated 2 1/2 stars, so I wasn't expecting much but I was pleasently surprised as to how much I enjoyed this movie from beginning to end. I want bored at all and thought the background cast were as good as the main actors and characters. Sure, there were some goofy characters and scenes, but were entertaining and funny. I really liked this movie and will watch it again, which is rare for me. Jennifer Lopez is absolutely beautiful, stunning at times, and played this role exceptionally well, as did the other main characters.

review_title: An interesting story with a glimpse of Cinderella.
review_detailed_main:
Marisa Ventura is a single mother for her son Ty. She also works as a maid at a luxury hotel in New York. Marisa also has a dream. She would like to be promoted to hotel management.

Christopher "Chris" Marshall is a senatorial candidate. He stays as a guest at the hotel where Marisa works. Christopher is single, but he has a dog called Rufus.

During a working day, Marisa tries on an expensive coat. The garment belongs to Caroline Lane, one of the hotel's rich guests. Chris sees Marisa in the coat, thinks that she is Caroline and wants to get to know her. But can Marisa keep lying to Chris?

Yes, I have to say that I really like this movie. I think that the story is interesting, a bit inspiring, romantic and quite funny sometimes. I will also, in all honesty, say that I see a glimpse of Cinderella in "Maid in Manhattan". I like Marisa's character development and strength. And yes, she is beautiful too. So what do I miss in this movie? Hm, maybe a flashback from Marisa's or Christopher's former times. A bit more romance and humor would also have been nice, at least if you ask me.

But all in all, I think that this movie is very good. I don't regret watching it and yes, you should give it an honest chance.

review_title: Not As Unbearable As I Thought!
review_detailed_main: So it took me all my life to get through this movie in 2024. I don't know, it just didn't interest me at all even though it's always brought up in the romantic comedy/romance film chatter. Kind of like Two Weeks Notice, I'd see it was on tv, probably on a Saturday afternoon on TBS or USA Network or something, I'd try to watch it for 10 minutes, hated it, and gave up (and probably went to rewatch The Holiday). But 2024 is the year I fill in romcom gaps so I decided to see it and guys I gotta say for a non-Italian JLo role, it's not half bad lol. I like her Italian roles more, namely The Wedding Planner, as she's fittingly playing herself instead of some characatured "brown" woman. Look up Juliet Hooker. Anyway, back to the film, politically it didn't age well, like at all, AT ALL, but romanceically it actually hit?? Like their chemistry was really believable and palpable. The eye acting alone was really lovely lol and there was spicy banter which is so romance novel!! Of course, Teen Wolf baby boy was 50 percent of the charm of the movie and also all the side characters. Like Stanley Tucci's dry humor alone was more interesting than anything Voldemort's ass had to say. Overall a nice time, and a classic. It's such a great time capsule of the early aughts.
